title-group.article-title: Damage assessment of fibre reinforced composites using shape descriptors

abstract.p: This study explores the use of a generic shape descriptor for quantitative comparisons between the full-field strain data acquired from virgin and damaged composite panels using digital image correlation. These descriptors are capable of decomposing images with 103 to 106 pixels into a feature vector with less than a few hundred elements. Strain distributions in four composite specimens with incremental impact damage and a virgin specimen, all subject to a tensile load, were decomposed using the newly developed Fourier–Zernike descriptors. Pearson’s correlation coefficient, cosine similarity and Euclidean distance were employed to compare quantitatively the feature vectors evaluated for the strain distributions in the four damaged specimens with the strain distribution in the virgin specimen. The deviation of the Pearson correlation coefficient from unity was found to be an effective damage indicator, which could be evaluated automatically and without the need for subjective assessment of the damage.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fibre-reinforced polymer composites possess high strength to weight ratios that makes them attractive for lightweight structures in which a high level of structural integrity needs to be maintained. This attribute is advantageous in the design of energy-efficient components for automobiles and aircraft. However, uncertainties associated with predicting their fatigue life and their post-damage load-carrying capacity have limited their widespread use. The standard practice, for handling the latter issue, is to replace a damaged composite component at the earliest indication of damage.

A wide variety of approaches to damage assessment in composites have been developed including: non-destructive testing, modal analysis or vibration characterization and strain measurement. These techniques can be classified based on the level of damage information provided by them.1

list-item.p: Level 2: Level 1 plus determination of location of damage;
Level 3: Level 2 plus determination of the extent of damage;
Level 4: Level 3 plus post-damage life estimation.

sec.p: The cost implications associated with the down-time and replacement of damaged components is a major factor limiting the more widespread use of composites. Thus, it is advantageous to obtain reliable Level 4 information, to allow the continued and safe operation of composite components, whenever possible. Classical techniques of non-destructive evaluation provide Level 1 and Level 2 information while strain measurement techniques have the potential to provide Level 3 information. Strain-based techniques offer the opportunity to discriminate between inconsequential damage that does not alter the strain pattern significantly and damage that raises the strain-level significantly thus precipitating premature failure. This type of information is at the boundary between Levels 3 and 4 described above.

Optical methods of strain analysis can provide full-field maps of strain although, in general, they are capable of acquiring strain data only on the surface of a component. However, Richardson et al.2 were able to detect an internal delamination in a composite panel using both the intensity fringes and the phase map recorded using Electronic Speckle Pattern Interferometry (ESPI). The effect of an internal delamination on the strain distribution at the surface of the laminate made its detection possible, although it was not possible to identify the exact depth of the delamination within the composite. Similarly, Horn et al.3 used thermoelastic stress analysis (TSA) to detect damage and assess its severity, including the residual fatigue life of the damaged composite. However, they did not utilize the full-field data recorded from TSA and instead, evaluated a stress concentration factor for the maximum stress in the vicinity of the damage normalized by the far-field stress. They assumed that this damage stress concentration factor was a direct measure of the level of damage as well as the residual life of the composite. Thus, this approach is similar in concept to the one proposed by Caprino4 who evaluated the residual strength as a ratio of the failure load of damaged and undamaged specimens. More recently, Fruehmann et al.5 have generated full-field strain maps using TSA in an attempt to relate the information to damage and residual fatigue life.

Thus, full-field strain distributions obtained from damaged composite components can provide useful information about the residual structural integrity through comparison with strain maps from an undamaged component. It may also be viable to distinguish the severity as well as different types of damage via comparative assessment of strain maps. Optical methods of strain analysis, such as ESPI, TSA and digital image correlation (DIC), typically yield data-rich maps of strain information at 106 pixels; so that a pixel-to-pixel comparison of such strain maps is computationally expensive and often impractical. Recent work6 has shown that information-preserving image decomposition techniques can be used to describe data-rich strain maps using, 102 or less, invariant shape features or descriptors. These decomposition techniques have been used for feature recognition, medical imagery, military targeting and biometric recognition for over a decade. In this work it is proposed that such techniques can be used to efficiently and effectively compare data-rich maps of strain in composite laminates with varying degrees of damage, and to provide a quantitative measure of the severity of the damage, in terms of its effect on structural integrity.

Geometric moment invariants are global region-based shape descriptors that were first applied to two-dimensional (2D) pattern recognition applications by Hu7 in 1962. Twenty-years later, Teague8 was the first to report the use of Zernike and Legendre polynomials to form Zernike moments and Legendre moments respectively, for image analysis. The orthogonal nature of Legendre and Zernike polynomials ensures that there is no redundancy in creating an accurate representation of the described image. Recently, Zhang and Lu9 proposed that normalized coefficients of the 2D Fourier transform of an image can be used as descriptors, and Wang et al.10–12 have used them for modal shape recognition and updating of computational models. These descriptors tend to be easier to compute and exhibit better information-preservation than contour-based descriptors and most region-based descriptors, such as Zernike moments;13 however Fourier descriptors do not achieve any data compression. This combination of advantages and disadvantages led Patki and Patterson6,14 to propose a new shape descriptor viz. the Fourier–Zernike descriptors in which Zernike moments are evaluated for the Fourier transform of a strain map. This new descriptor exhibited better information preservation than Zernike moments for strain maps containing discontinuities which arise at engineered features, such as holes or cut-outs, and in the vicinity of damage; while also achieving better data compression than Fourier descriptors. Data-rich strain maps containing information at 106 pixels can be uniquely and accurately described by less than 102 moments using the Fourier–Zernike approach. Thus, it is proposed in this work that, quantitative comparisons of such maps from damaged composite laminates becomes relatively straightforward using similarity measures such as the Pearson correlation coefficient, cosine similarity or Euclidean distances.

sec.title: Image processing methodology
sec.p: Digital image correlation (DIC) can be employed to obtain full-field maps of displacement which can be differentiated to yield maps of strain in a component that typically contain 103 to 106 pixels of data. A pixel-by-pixel comparison of two such data sets is computationally expensive and often impractical. Image decomposition employs image or shape description techniques to condense such data-rich strain maps into a small number of shape descriptors that can be contained in a feature vector which makes comparisons easier and computationally acceptable. These image description techniques must possess certain properties in order to qualify as reliable and accurate, that is:

list-item.p: the techniques must be computational efficient;
the feature vector should be invariant under affine transformations, i.e. a rotation and translation;
the image representation should be unique so that an image can be easily retrieved from a feature vector.

sec.title: Experimental procedures
sec.p: Five rectangular specimens (240 mm × 60 mm) as shown in Figure 2 were machined, using a diamond saw, from a 3.5 mm thick sheet of an off-the-shelf glass fibre reinforced polymer matrix composite (CYCOM® 1004, CYTEC Industries Ltd, New Jersey) made up of nine cross-plies in the [0/90/0/90/0/90/0/90/0]° configuration with a resin content of 36±3% by weight. Four specimens were subjected to impacts using a drop-weight testing machine in which the impact-energy was kept low enough to ensure that the hemi-spherical tup, of diameter 15 mm, did not penetrate the specimen. The drop weight was kept constant and the height was varied so that the impact-energy varied from 30 J, for specimen #1, to 37.3 J, for specimen #4, in nominal increments of 2.5 J. The fifth specimen was not subject to any impact loading. C-scan and time of flight images were obtained for each specimen using an UltraPAC II® ultrasonic system (Physical Acoustics Corporation, Princeton Jct., New Jersey, USA).

caption.p: Undamaged (left) and progressively more damaged (from left) glass fiber reinforced polymer composite specimens orientated with their longitudinal axes vertical and with specimens numbers at top.

sec.p: Prior to loading in a 50,000 N MTS® servo-hydraulic loading machine, aluminium tabs were glued to each side of the composite specimens at the ends to provide a location for gripping the specimen. These metal tabs protected the specimens from failure due to excessive crushing forces in the hydraulic grips of the loading machine, and provided for a uniform and gradual load transfer from the hydraulic grips to the specimen. The face of the specimens were spray-painted white and then a black speckle pattern was sprayed onto the surface to provide suitable features for digital image correlation using commercially available paint (Krylon Extra Flat (White and Black); Krylon Inc., Cleveland, OH) supplied in spray cans. A single pass over the specimen from a range of about 30cm was used with the white paint so that a fine uniform speckle was produced as shown in Figure 3. Each specimen was subjected to tensile loading in increments of 667 N from 0 N to a maximum load of 8000 N. At each increment of loading, images were captured using a high resolution (2048×2048 pixel) charge-coupled device (CCD) camera located 0.5 m from the non-impacted surface of the specimen that was illuminated by a HILIS cold light system (Q-400 – Dantec Dynamics, Denmark), which provided uniform illumination. The experiments were repeated to obtain six sets of data for a statistical comparison.

caption.p: Composite specimen with an impacted hole shown with a speckle pattern obtained using white and black spray paint.

sec.p: The DIC system was calibrated using the calibration plate provided with the system and the correlation was performed using the default facet size of 17 pixels with an overlap of 5 pixels so that displacement vectors were obtained for an array with a spacing of 12 pixels. These displacement datasets were differentiated to obtain full-field maps of the strain using the standard algorithm supplied with the Istra4D operating system of the Q400 DIC system. The use of overlapping facets increases the spatial density of the displacement data and reduces the noise induced in the strain field by the differentiation process. Fourier–Zernike moments, Nmax = 20, were evaluated for each strain map using a Matlab® code, ImPaCT (Image Pattern Comparison Technique) developed by Patki,16 which also provided a reconstruction of the decomposed strain map so that the level of information preservation could be assessed.

The image descriptors were employed to make a quantitative comparison of the strain maps from each damaged specimen with the undamaged, virgin specimen using the following similarity measures: Pearson’s correlation coefficient, cosine similarity and Euclidean distance.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: C-scan images of the damaged specimens are shown in Figures 4 and 5 together with time of flight data in Figure 6. The images in Figure 4 are from the face that was not impacted and which was on the bottom in the ultrasonic setup so that the images show the superposition of the delaminations between all of the layers. Figure 5 shows C-scan images of the impacted face which was the top surface in the ultrasonic set-up and shows the delamination only between this surface layer and the layer immediately below it. The time of flight images shown in Figure 6 were used to estimate the amount of delamination between each layer of the composite laminate since longer times are white and shorter ones black so that delaminations further away from the sensor are shown in light grey.

sec.p: Maps of maximum principal strain, for the specimens subject to the maximum tensile load of 8000N, together with the corresponding Fourier–Zernike moments are shown in Figure 7 for the five specimens. Figure 8 shows trends in the similarity measures with level of damage for the Fourier–Zernike moments using the map of the maximum principal strain in the virgin specimen as the basis for comparison, i.e. Pearson’s correlation coefficient and the cosine similarity would have a value of unity for the virgin specimen. These similarity measures exhibit values that decrease with increasing impact energy, implying that the strain distribution deviates further away from the corresponding strain distribution in the virgin composite specimen with increasing levels of damage. The Euclidean distance measured between the Fourier–Zernike moments is zero for the virgin specimen and increases with the increasing level of damage.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results shown in Figures 4, 5 and 6 from the ultrasound investigations provide a qualitative indication of the extent of damage in the impacted specimens. However, a quantitative measure was sought to allow comparison with the new measures proposed in the study. Thus, an attempt was made to quantify these results by assessing the maximum length along the longitudinal (loading) axis of the specimen, the maximum width in the transverse direction and the area of the damage from the time of flight data in Figure 6. Since the strain maps described using the Zernike-Fourier moments were obtained from the opposite face to the impact surface, the size of delamination between this surface layer and the adjacent one were measured. The area of delamination was evaluated using a Matlab® code specially developed for this purpose which applied a threshold to the data to form a binary image of the specimen such that the regions without delamination were black and those with delamination were white. The area of the white regions together with the maximum length and width of the delamination were normalized by simply dividing the absolute values with those corresponding to the 30J impact event. These normalized dimensions of the delamination area are plotted in Figure 9 as a function of impact energy. The extent of delamination, in terms of length, width, and consequently, the projected area of delamination, increases with impact energy. These findings are consistent with the values reported previously by Paget et al.17 and exhibit a similar trend to the Euclidean distance similarity coefficient in Figure 8. The increase in width of the projected area of delamination with increasing energy of impact is less compared to the increase in its length, which is depicted by the difference in the slopes of the corresponding trend lines in Figure 9. Also, the projected area of delamination seems to have a better correlation with the energy of impact with an R2 value of 0.9082 than the length and width of delamination with R2 values of 0.8775 and 0.8684 respectively. The term ‘projected area’ is used here because areas of delamination for all eight interfaces between the nine cross-plies were projected through the thickness and treated as a single area of damage, i.e. all the grey levels representing damage in Figure 6 were treated as if they were a single delamination.

caption.p: Maximum length in the longitudinal direction, maximum width in the transverse direction and area of damage based on the time of flight data in Figure 5, as a function of impact energy.

sec.p: In Figure 8, it is apparent that both the Pearson coefficient and cosine similarity deviate from unity as the energy of the impact is increased and also with the length, width and area of the damage found using ultrasound. The unity value indicates there is perfect correlation between the pair of strain distributions being compared, which in this case would imply no damage because the comparator is the virgin specimen. The trend is reversed for the Euclidean distance, which increases with the impact energy and the size of the damage zone identified with ultrasound. This is expected since the Euclidean distance is a measure of the distance between the feature vectors for the virgin and damaged specimen which would increase as the strain field is altered by growing levels of damage. It is worthwhile to consider the linearity of the plots in Figure 8 by assuming R2>0.9025 (R>95%) indicates a linear correlation, and then, Euclidean distance is linear with all damage measurements, Pearson coefficient with all except width, and cosine distance only with area. As discussed above, the area of damage exhibits the strongest correlation with impact energy and, amongst the similarity coefficients, the Pearson coefficient shows the strongest correlation with both the extent or projected area of damage (R2=0.9478) and impact energy (R2 = 0.9927). This seems a reasonable argument for preferring the Pearson coefficient. The stress concentration factor associated with the damage was also evaluated and found to have R2 values of 0.9068 and 0.9895 when plotted as a linear relationship with the projected area of delamination and impact energy, respectively. So, it can be concluded that the use of the complete strain map represented by the feature vector provides a better correlation with damage than using the strain concentration at a single point.

It is more useful, perhaps, to have a damage indicator that takes a value of zero when there is no damage present. Such an indicator can be easily generated by subtracting the Pearson coefficient, described above, from 1. The resultant ‘damage indicator’ is shown in Figure 10 as a function of both the projected area of damage and the impact energy. It forms a linear relationship with impact energy with a high correlation coefficient (0.9532) but is below the threshold for assuming linearity with the projected area of damage. The most effective test of the usefulness of this damage indicator would to examine its relationship with the residual strength and remnant life of composites following damage. This is planned as the next step in this work. However, the techniques described here, have the significant advantage of providing a means of automatically processing strain distributions related to damage and of generating a quantitative measure of damage without any subjective judgments by an operator. A variant on the procedure followed here, would be to replace the strain distribution measured in the virgin specimen with one generated from a computational model of the component being evaluated, which would allow the technique to be used for quality assurance during manufacturing and tracking of the condition of a component during its life-cycle. In these circumstances, it might have to be accepted that perfect correlation between the strain distribution from a physical sample and the computational model would never be achieved, and so an acceptable level of correlation would need to be defined. Such a level of correlation would need to take account of the uncertainties associated with the strain measurement system which could be assessed using a suitable calibration procedure.18

caption.p: Damage indicator (=1 – Pearson coefficient) as a function of area of damage, measured using ultrasound, and impact energy.

sec.p: The novel technique proposed here is based on surface strain measurements and in the form described here is not able to distinguish between delamination at different interfaces, unlike some traditional non-destructive testing techniques. However, it has the significant advantage that the strain field data can be used for a quantitative assessment of the structural prognosis, i.e. Level 4 information. It is possible that thermoelastic stress analysis, as opposed to digital image correlation used here, could allow damage at interfaces between the different laminates through the thickness of the fibre reinforced composite to be identified and quantified by using different loading frequencies.

Further work is necessary to define precisely the limits of this new approach in terms of the depth of significant damage that can be identified and quantified; however, the potential of the new approach has been clearly demonstrated.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This work demonstrates the ability of Fourier–Zernike moment descriptors to provide a basis for full-field structural damage assessment in fibre reinforced composites. Fourier analysis and Zernike moment shape descriptors have been combined to obtain a generic shape descriptor.

Similarity measures including Pearson’s correlation coefficient, cosine similarity and Euclidean distance were used to evaluate the similarity between feature vectors representing the strain distributions in damaged and virgin specimens subject to tensile loading. It was observed the Pearson’s correlation coefficient, Euclidean distance and cosine similarity showed a linear trend with respect to increasing impact damage, which was comparable to the corresponding trend in the stress concentration factor in the composite specimens due to impact damage. However, the Pearson coefficient exhibited less scatter and was preferred as a damage indicator.

The statistical correlation of Fourier–Zernike shape descriptors representing data-rich maps in a dimensionally reduced form, provides a fast means of identifying and quantifying damage relative to a virgin composite component, which is computationally efficient and can be completely automated so that no subjective judgment is required. The use of strain distributions for quantifying composite damage creates the opportunity to achieve Level 4 damage quantification, i.e. post-damage life estimation, and links non-destructive evaluation directly to structural prognoses.
